title: “Visual Affluence” in Social Photography: Applicability of Image Segmentation as a Visually Oriented Approach to Study Instagram Hashtags
location: ["University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom", "Middlesex University, London, United Kingdom"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Image segmentation can be used as a meaning-independent measure of visual richness in social media images.
• Images with complex textures and detailed backgrounds show higher visual affluence than images with blur or flat backgrounds.
• Different Instagram hashtags exhibit statistically significant differences in visual affluence.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Limited sample size and non-normal distributions across hashtag datasets
• Dependence on threshold values for image segmentation
• Data collected before Instagram API access restrictions
Notes: Methodological contribution introducing “visual affluence” as a scalable, non-semantic visual metric; emphasizes visually oriented analysis over meaning-based interpretation.

the focus on a single platform, Twitter.

Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Tourists’ chromatic perceptions differ systematically between dark and red heritage tourism sites.

• User cultural background was not differentiated.

title: Memes, brands and the politics of post-terror togetherness: following the Manchester bee after the 2017 Manchester Arena bombing
location: Umeå Universitet, Department of Sociology, Umea, Sweden
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• The Manchester bee became a unifying meme expressing post-terror togetherness across online and offline spaces.
• Grassroots memeification preceded and enabled institutional brand adoption by city authorities.
• Official branding later obscured political tensions related to exclusion, gentrification, and far-right appropriation.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Instagram users are demographically skewed, limiting representativeness.
• Analysis privileges highly visible and highly digital responses over less visible forms of mourning.
• Machine-learning clustering requires subjective interpretation by researchers.
Notes: Strong example of mixed-method visual social media research combining computational image analysis with critical qualitative interpretation.

• Experience-related features most strongly influence ratings and sentiment
• Different town types emphasize different visual and experiential features
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Reliance on a single platform.
• Limited causal inference; regional concentration in China.
• Potential user bias in social media data.
Notes: Strong example of interpretable multimodal ML (CLIP + XGBoost + SHAP) applied to large-scale visual social media data

title: Rally ’Round the Mask: Congressional Social Media Images and Masking during COVID-19
location: ["Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, Ireland", "University of Exeter, Centre for Climate Communication and Data Science, Exeter, United Kingdom", "University of Houston, Hobby School, Houston, United States"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Members of Congress increased mask-related imagery during key COVID-19 moments
• Partisan differences existed but were moderated by crisis events
• Trump’s behavior strongly influenced Republican visual messaging
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Focuses only on US congressional elites.
• Image interpretation limited to mask detection.
• Does not measure audience reception.
Notes: Large-scale automated visual analysis using CNNs; strong example of political image-as-data research

title: Short, Long, and Segmented Learning Videos: From YouTube Practice to Enhanced Video Players
location: FernUniversität in Hagen, Hagen, Germany
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Short and segmented videos dominate educational YouTube practice
• Segmented videos significantly improve learning outcomes
• Video player design matters more than video length alone
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Small user-study sample.
• Platform-specific findings.
• Inability to capture attention quality
Notes: Large-scale YouTube metadata study combined with experimental validation; focuses on video structure rather than visual content semantics

title: Social Media as a Lens for Citizen Science: Investigating Visitor Contributions in a Forest Recreational Area
location: ["Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, Department of Forest Management, Tsukuba, Japan", "University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan", "National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Biodiversity Division, Tsukuba, Japan"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Social media platforms like Google Maps provide dense, spatially explicit biodiversity and recreation data even for small areas.
• Users fall into distinct behavioral clusters, which influence what they photograph.
• Repeat visitors tend to act as seasonal ecological observers, documenting plant phenology such as spring blossoms.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Social media data may not reflect full visitor behavior.
• Posts may be deleted in future, no guarantee of stability.
• Focus on one site and one platform limits generalizability.
Notes: This paper is heavy on taxonomy development, behavior clustering, and implications for recruiting citizen scientists. No automated computer vision or NLP.

title: TCE-DBF: textual context enhanced dynamic bimodal fusion for hate video detection
location: Beijing Technology and Business University, School of Computer and Artificial Intelligence, Beijing, China
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Proposed TCE-DBF multimodal fusion model significantly outperforms existing hate-video classifiers. 
• Text extracted from video frames (OCR) greatly strengthens prediction accuracy. 
• Text modality contributes the most weight during multimodal fusion (shown via DMG visualization).
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Text modality dominates, causing potential overreliance. 
• OCR quality varies across videos. 
• Dataset may not generalize across platforms. 
• Model may overfit after certain epochs.
Notes: Highly technical multimodal deep learning paper; strong emphasis on OCR and audio-text synergy; not traditional social-science image analysis.
QC Flags: Study time window not in YYYY or YYYY-YYYY (manual check)

title: Tech, Sex, and E-cigarettes: The Gendering of Vape Promotion on Instagram
location: ["University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, United States", "Lehigh University, Department of English Language & Literature, Bethlehem, United States", "Lehigh University, Department of Journalism and Communication, Bethlehem, United States"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Gender strongly shapes vape influencer content strategies: women emphasized self-objectification; men emphasized technical expertise. ￼
• Male influencers more frequently posted product-only images, focusing on device parts, customization, and technical mastery.
• Female influencers more frequently posted themselves, showing bodies, faces, tattoos, and sexualized imagery, sometimes without any vape product at all.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Gender coding based on visual inference, not self-reported
• Does not include non-binary identities
• Influencer-focused dataset not representative
• Engagement metrics limited by platform norms
Notes:
Strong integration of feminist theory, objectification theory, and influencer studies.
Useful exemplar of combining textual and visual coding at scale.

title: The “memeification” of sexual health communication on Instagram
location: ["University of Miami, School of Nursing and Health Studies, Coral Gables, United States", "The City University of New York, Department of Community Health and Social Sciences, New York, United States", "Yale University, New Haven, United States"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Memes significantly outperformed all other post types in likes, shares, saves, reach, and impressions. ￼
• Memes helped convert Instagram followers into podcast listeners, supporting multi-platform sexual health engagement.
• Most common meme themes were relationships (35.6%) and sex positivity (22.7%), showing strong user resonance.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Instagram does not allow full retroactive analytics retrieval
• Posting-time data unavailable
• Some insight metrics affected by COVID-19 disruptions
• Instagram’s gender reporting is binary
Notes: Case study of a sexual-health intervention using meme-based communication. Strong use of Instagram analytics; highly descriptive metrics-driven study.

title: The impact of visual, auditory, textual stimuli on crowdfunding: evidence from tourism projects
location: ["University of Macau, Department of Integrated Resort and Tourism Management, Taipa, Macao", "Hainan University, Department of Tourism Management, Haikou, China"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Text is the strongest predictor of crowdfunding success; video is moderately predictive, images are weakest. 
• Higher video resolution, more scenes, and greater visual variation improve prediction of success. 
• Multimodal combinations outperform any single stimulus; content consistency across modalities has limited predictive benefit.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Data from only one platform (Indiegogo). 
• Focuses on prediction rather than explanation. 
• Does not examine sequencing of stimuli users see.
Notes: Highly technical multimodal ML pipeline; rare example integrating image + video + audio + text in tourism crowdfunding forecasting.
QC Flags: Study time window not in YYYY or YYYY-YYYY (manual check)

title: The memeification of China’s Twitter diplomacy, 2019–2022: Adding memes to the toolkit of China’s wolf warrior diplomats
location: Aarhus Universitet, Aarhus, Denmark
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Memes significantly increased engagement and virality in Chinese digital diplomacy.
• Playful and sarcastic visual memes amplified ideological confrontation with the US and NATO.
• Meme use disrupted traditional diplomatic norms and blurred propaganda and popular culture.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Focus limited to Twitter.
• difficulty assessing audience interpretation.
• emphasis on highly visible accounts.
Notes: Large-scale mixed-method study combining computational analysis and qualitative meme analysis. Strong example of DS + visual social media research.

title: The Popularity Gap: Effects of Social Status on the Visibility of Lifestyle Sports Stars on Instagram
location: West Virginia University, Department of Sociology and Anthropology, Morgantown, United States
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Gender, dominance, and physical attractiveness significantly influence Instagram popularity
• High-status athletes receive disproportionate visibility independent of effort
• Visual self-branding does not fully offset structural inequalities
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Sample limited to one sport; focus on one platform
• findings may not generalize to other athletic domains
Notes: Visual analysis combined with statistical modeling; no automated image analysis

title: The visual vaccine debate on twitter: A social network analysis
location: ["University of the West of England, Department of Applied Sciences, Bristol, United Kingdom", "University of the West of England, Department of Health and Social Sciences, Bristol, United Kingdom"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Anti-vaccine and pro-vaccine users form two polarized, isolated networks that rarely interact.
• Anti-vaccine images spread within dense clusters dominated by activists and parents; pro-vaccine clusters are more fragmented and led by NGOs.
• Anti-vaccine images reach broader visibility through high internal retweeting, potentially amplifying misinformation.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Twitter’s structure may shift over time; findings not generalizable beyond 2016.
• Manual classification risks subjective interpretation.
• Lack of geolocation and demographic metadata limits contextual interpretation.
Notes: Focuses specifically on image-sharing patterns, not textual content alone, adds novel insight into visual misinformation dynamics.

title: Uncovering gender stereotypes in controversial science discourse: evidence from computational text and visual analyses across digital platforms
location: ["University of Wisconsin-Madison, Department of Life Sciences Communication, Madison, United States", "University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States", "University of Iowa, School of Journalism and Mass Communication, Iowa City, United States"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Gender stereotypes strongly structure digital science discourse. Women are associated with care, children, health; men with conspiracy & misinformation. 
• Clear cross-platform differences: YouTube emphasizes women’s moral language; TikTok emphasizes men/authority language. 
• Thumbnails also reflect stereotypes: women shown in vlog-style selfies or as activists; men shown in conspiracy-themed imagery.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Data skew toward highly viewed YouTube videos. 
• limited exploration of platform-specific mechanisms. 
• gender stereotypes may evolve. 
• limited misinformation lexicon.
Notes: Uses multimodal analysis—text + thumbnails; applies Social Identity Model of Deindividuation (SIDE); explores gender-neutral vs gendered language engagement.

title: Using geo-data and social media images to explore the supply and demand of cultural ecosystem services for terraces in China
location: ["Beijing Forestry University, School of Landscape Architecture, Beijing, China", "University College London, London, United Kingdom"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• High cultural ecosystem service (CES) supply and demand clusters are concentrated in southeastern and southwestern China.
• EfficientNet-B3 achieved 92% accuracy in classifying social media images into seven CES-related categories.
• There is a significant positive spatial autocorrelation between CES supply and demand (Moran’s I = 0.372).
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Social media demographic bias
• Subjective interpretation of images
• Geotagging inaccuracies
• Difficulty mapping intangible CES
Notes: Primarily an environmental science / GIS research paper rather than social-science analysis of social-media imagery, but it uses CNNs on social media images, so it fits your project criteria

title: Valuing cultural ecosystem services combining deep learning and benefit transfer approach
location: ["The University of British Columbia, Department of Forest Resources Management, Vancouver, Canada", "ETH Zürich, Department of Environmental Systems Science, Zurich, Switzerland"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Deep learning CNNs achieved 85% accuracy in classifying cultural ecosystem service imagery.
• Flickr images reveal distinct recreational and aesthetic patterns across BC parks.
• Combining CNN outputs with benefit-transfer economics estimated large monetary values for recreation services.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Flickr demographic bias and declining popularity
• Underrepresentation of certain activities
• Transfer learning limits CNN adaptability
• Some CES categories difficult to detect visually
• Possible misclassification between hiking/climbing/water-related
Notes: Highly methodological paper demonstrating deep learning for automated CES assessment + economic valuation. Strong emphasis on CNN architecture, training pipeline, and benefit transfer methodology.

title: Vandalism as Symbolic Reparation Imaginaries of Protest in Nicaragua
location: University of the Arts London, London, United Kingdom
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Protest vandalism in Nicaragua functions as symbolic reparation, reclaiming political meaning. 
• Social media imagery played a central role in circulating revolutionary iconography and shaping political imaginaries. 
• Similar visual protest practices in Chile and Mexico reveal a shared repertoire of iconoclasm and public-space interventions across Latin America.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Protest imagery is ephemeral and difficult to archive. 
• Social media material is fragmented and may bias interpretations. 
• Acts labelled as “vandalism” are politically contested, complicating analysis.
Notes: Focuses on visual protest practices and symbolic meaning; strong anthropological and theoretical framing; no computational methods; imagery used mainly for narrative/interpretive purposes.

title: Video source camera identification using fusion of texture features and noise fingerprint
location: National Institute of Technology Tiruchirappalli, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Tiruchirappalli, India
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Higher Order Wavelet Statistics fused with PRNU, LBP, and GLCM features greatly improve video source app identification accuracy.
• ExtraTrees classifier achieved ~99.96% accuracy in identifying which instant messaging app encoded a video.
• Re-encoding by IMAs introduces unique traces that can be used to identify the transmission source for forensic purposes.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• PRNU severely affected by video compression and high-texture content
• Results may differ on real-world, user-generated videos
• Only Android IMAs tested; limited device diversity
• Feature extraction computationally heavy
Notes: Highly technical forensic CV study; not a social-media content analysis paper. Still relevant if reviewing image-processing methods applied to media circulated online.
QC Flags: Study time window not in YYYY or YYYY-YYYY (manual check)

title: Visual Attributes of Thumbnails in Predicting YouTube Brand Channel Views in the Marketing Digitalization Era
journal: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
location: ["Handong Global University, School of Communication Arts and Science, Pohang, South Korea", "Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon, South Korea", "Handong Global University, School of Global Entrepreneurship and Information Communication Technology, Pohang, South Korea", "Pohang University of Science and Technology, School of Convergence Science and Technology, Pohang, South Korea", "Handong Global University, School of Economics and Management, Pohang, South Korea"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Offline brand ranking, subscriber count, number of channel videos, thumbnail brightness, and thumbnail colorfulness strongly predict view counts. ￼
• SVM achieved the best performance (MAPE ≈ 1.99%). ￼
• Purposefully designed thumbnails outperform automatically generated ones; visual design significantly shapes viewer selection.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Only Korean YouTube brand channels analyzed, limited generalizability.
• Thumbnail "optimal" brightness/color not precisely determined.
• Need external factors.
• Need experiments comparing different thumbnails for same video.
Notes:
• Strongly visual-focused methodology.
• Heavy integration of computer vision + machine learning.
• Combines brand metadata, channel metadata, and thumbnail image attributes.

title: Visual cross-platform analysis: digital methods to research social media images
location: ["The University of Sheffield, iHuman, Sheffield, United Kingdom", "The University of Sheffield, Department of Sociological Studies, Sheffield, United Kingdom", "University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, English Language and Literature, Ann Arbor, United States", "Dublin City University, School of Communications, Dublin, Ireland", "Universität Potsdam, Faculty of Economics and Social Sciences, Potsdam, Germany", "Universidade Nova de Lisboa, iNOVA Media Lab, Lisbon, Portugal", "Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Institute of Social Medicine, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Each platform exhibits a distinct visual vernacular, shaped by both culture and affordances.
• Cross-platform differences show that images circulate more effectively on Twitter than Instagram despite Instagram being the “visual” platform.
• Visual methods such as image-text networks and composite images can reveal macro- and meso-level patterns in climate change communication.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Dataset relies on text-based retrieval, which can miss visually relevant content.
• API access creates structural bias.
• Image reposting patterns differ by platform, complicating comparability.
Notes: Study focuses on methodological development rather than theory-building about climate change visuals.

title: Visual information and appearance: The impact of visual attributes of user-generated photos on review helpfulness
location: ["Shanghai International Studies University, School of Business and Management, Shanghai, China", "Shanghai International Studies University, School of Business and Management, Shanghai, China"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Visual breadth and visual depth significantly increase perceived review helpfulness.
• Image aesthetics alone does not increase review helpfulness.
• Reviewer status and review text length strengthen the effects of visual information on helpfulness.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Missing additional visual categories such as service.
• U.S. only restaurant platform, generalizability limited.
• Moderate dataset size, suggest larger datasets in future.
Notes: Advanced use of YOLOv5 + NIMA makes this a strong computational-visual analysis example; strong mapping to ELM theory.

title: Visual media analysis for Instagram and other online platforms
location: Universiteit van Amsterdam, Media Studies, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Introduces “metapictures” as analytical visual arrangements enabling both close and distant reading of visual social media.
• Demonstrates methods including image similarity grouping, image composites, dominant image detection, content moderation analysis, and cross-platform comparison.
• Shows how visual datasets can reveal platform vernaculars, political alignment, misinformation patterns, and content moderation differences.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Visual analysis is constrained by platform access restrictions.
• Metadata availability varies widely across platforms.
• API restrictions hinder reproducibility.
• Automated labeling often does not capture social meaning.
Notes: Highly methodological; provides demonstrations rather than one empirical dataset. Excellent reference for visual social media analysis methods.
QC Flags: Study time window not in YYYY or YYYY-YYYY (manual check)

title: Visual Narratives and Digital Engagement: Decoding Seoul and Tokyo’s Tourism Identity Through Instagram Analytics
location: Ewha Womans University, Department of Communication & Media, Seoul, South Korea
Other dataset size (e.g., posts/users):
~29,985 posts for Seoul
~29,959 posts for Tokyo
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Tokyo posts received significantly more likes, while Seoul posts elicited more comments and stronger emotional engagement.
• Seoul had more posts on landmarks/architecture, Tokyo more on food; overall “person” was the dominant category.
• Engagement drivers differ: hashtags matter most for Seoul, presence of people/animals matters most for Tokyo.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Lower geotag availability in Tokyo introduces spatial uncertainty
• Dataset covers a limited time period (2018–2019)
• Broad content categories reduce granularity
• Instagram-only sample limits generalizability
Notes:
• Extensive mixed-methods pipeline integrating CNN, sentiment analysis, geospatial clustering, and SHAP.
• Strong methodological transparency and validation steps.
• Highly relevant to your review because it uses large-scale visual social media analysis with computational tools.

title: Visualizing digital traces for sustainable urban management: Mapping tourism activity on the virtual public space
location: ["Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya, Department of Architectural Representation, Barcelona, Spain", "Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya, Department of Architectural Technology, Barcelona, Spain"]
Other dataset size (e.g., posts/users): 4,283 Flickr users; 10,908 unique location strings; 5693 geocoded locations.
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Geotagged social media images can accurately map real-world tourist behavior and hotspot areas. ￼
• Clear differences between local vs. tourist photographic activity: tourists concentrate heavily around landmarks; locals show dispersed patterns.
• Visualization techniques (treemaps, KDE, rasterization) provide actionable insights for sustainable tourism policies.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Flickr bias toward Western users
• Convenience sample issues
• Potential loss of access if platforms restrict data
Notes: Strong methodological contribution focused on spatial statistics, KDE, and data visualization for planners.

title: Visualizing environmental management: Corporate environmental images information disclosure and idiosyncratic risk
location: ["Hefei University of Technology, School of Management, Hefei, China", "Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Key Laboratory of Process Optimization and Intelligent Decision-making, Beijing, China", "Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, China"]
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Companies increasingly disclose environmental images, especially environmental awareness visuals (>50% yearly).
• Environmental image disclosure is negatively associated with idiosyncratic risk, meaning more visual disclosure = lower financial risk.
• When companies experience negative environmental events or have high idiosyncratic risk, image disclosure becomes impression management and no longer reduces risk.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Image categories may be imperfect representations.
• Only covers environmentally sensitive firms in China.
• Does not incorporate textual environmental disclosures.
Notes: Very strong example of machine-learning automated image classification in social-media environmental research.

title: Visualizing the triple bottom line: A large-scale automated visual content analysis of European corporations' website and social media images
journal: Corporate Social Responsibility and Environmental Management
location: Universiteit van Amsterdam, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Companies overwhelmingly emphasize the profit dimension in visual CSR communication (web and Twitter).
• Firms post more people/planet/profit images on Twitter than websites, showing channel differences.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Machine vision APIs limited to basic semantic labels.
• Imbalance in image counts between platforms.
• Website scraping provides only a snapshot, cannot ensure temporal comparability.
• Twitter classifier performance differs from website classifier.
Notes: Automated visual analysis of >25k images, one of the earliest large-scale CV applications in CSR communication.

title: YouTube thumbnail design recommendation systems using image-tabular multimodal data for Thai’s YouTube thumbnail
location: National Institute of Development Administration, Graduate School of Applied Statistics, Bangkok, Thailand
Key findings (1–3 bullet points):
• Combined multimodal tabular + image features can predict high-performing YouTube thumbnails.
• Xception model achieved best classification accuracy (≈88%).
• Object detection + clustering revealed visual elements linked to higher engagement in Food, IT, and Travel categories.
Limitations (authors' statements):
• Need larger dataset
• Need region-specific training data
• Suggest adding object location, color tone, emotion cues in future work
Notes: Case report-style illustration of multimodal recommendation system for thumbnail optimization
